Translator: Reiko Bovee
Reviewer: Denise RQ

9.text:
Raise your hands
if you'd like to win the lottery.

19.text:
if in the past month,
you actually bought a lottery ticket.

25.text:
You don't need a psychologist to tell you
why you didn't buy those tickets.

32.text: Given the odds of winning the lottery,

34.text:
that might seem 
like a reasonable conclusion,

36.text: but what's important to learn here

38.text:
is that you act based on 
what you expect not what you want.

44.text:
What you want and what you expect
are completely different.

51.text:
about whether or not
you're going to get what you want.

55.text:
As a psychologist that studies 
how people create their futures,

58.text: one of the things I have learned

60.text:
that having an expectation
that differs from what you want

63.text:
isn't just the reason 
you don't buy lottery tickets.

67.text:
It’s the reason why there are
lots of things that you want,

71.text: but you can't quite seem to attain them.

74.text: Losing that last five to ten pounds,

77.text: going for that dream job or relationship,

81.text:
it's the reason why no matter
how hard you try to create change,

98.text:
It might surprise you to know
that most people go about their daily life

102.text:
thinking that they are acting 
on what they want,

106.text:
when in reality, they are acting 
on their expectations.

109.text:
I was working with a client
of mine recently -

112.text: I’m going to call her Amy -

115.text: she was a gorgeous and successful woman,

117.text:
but she was also sort of shy,
very self-deprecating,

119.text:
and she had a history
of picking the wrong men.

123.text:
Amy had recently gotten out 
of a bad marriage.

126.text:
She worked on herself, so she
was ready to meet someone new.

129.text:
She decided that she was going
to give online dating a try.

132.text:
But she was having
one bad date after the next.

137.text: The men didn’t look like their pictures,

143.text: Some of them didn’t show up at all.

148.text:
One day Amy comes into my office,
and she immediately bursts into tears.

153.text: “I had the most awful date of my life.”

159.text: "Well how bad was he?" I asked.

165.text:
"Absolutely everything 
I had been looking for."

173.text:
I was so certain this was going
to be another bad date

175.text: and a waste of my time,

177.text:
I told him to meet me
for coffee after my yoga class.

183.text:
just showed up in my gym clothes,
hot and sweaty, no make-up.

193.text: tall and handsome, the perfect smile."

197.text:
She said, "I was so mortified,
and self-conscious,

200.text: I couldn’t even make eye contact.

202.text:
I just sat there, staring at the ground
laughing nervously,

205.text:
until finally I told him I had to put
more money in my parking meter,

215.text: Amy acted on what she expected,

224.text: which was to meet that great guy.

228.text:
I wish I could say this kind 
of behavior was uncommon.

233.text:
But having been in practice
for more than 12 years,

236.text: one of the things I hear most often

239.text: is "I want to change my life,

242.text: but I don’t really believe that I can."

246.text:
I'd seen people give up
on their marriages,

253.text: give up on their entire lives,

255.text:
because they didn’t think
they could get what they wanted,

257.text: and so they weren't willing to try.

261.text:
There is probably something
that you want, in your life right now,

267.text:
but you're not sure if you can attain it,
and so you're holding back.

273.text:
When you don’t act on what you want,
you take yourself out of the game.

280.text:
Buying that lottery ticket 
doesn't guarantee winning,

290.text: You might be wondering: why do we do this?

293.text:
Our brains work on the principle
of anticipation;

297.text:
we constantly predict what we think
is likely to happen before it ever occurs.

303.text:
If you’re walking in the park,
and you hear a dog barking behind you,

308.text: and then turn around to see big foot,

312.text: you’re going to be very surprised,

315.text:
although it would make
a really great selfie.

320.text:
As soon as you start
to anticipate any event,

324.text:
you begin to act and feel
in ways that help you prepare

328.text: for what you think is going to happen.

331.text: If anyone has ever said to you,

337.text: then you know exactly what I mean.

343.text:
When you prepare for something
that hasn’t even happened yet,

347.text: you participate in creating the outcome.

350.text:
In other words, you create
the self-fulfilling prophecy.

357.text:
Because Amy was acting anxious
and ambivalent before her date,

362.text:
she acted on what she expected
not on what she wanted,

364.text: and so she got what she expected;

371.text:
One of the reasons that our expectations
can keep us so stuck

374.text:
is we have an automatic tendency
to use the past to predict the future.

381.text:
If you failed once, you're likely
to think you might fail again.

385.text: When you think about the future,

388.text:
the same part of the brain gets activated
as when you think about the past.

393.text:
However, just because you use
the past to make predictions,

398.text:
doesn’t mean that your past
is what's holding you back.

403.text: What was holding Amy back wasn’t her past;

408.text:
it was that she didn’t believe
her future could be better than the past.

413.text:
Without that belief, she wasn't able
to create something better,

417.text:
even thought an opportunity had
presented itself right in front of her.

423.text:
If you're aware of what your
expectations are in a situation,

426.text:
then you have the ability
to use your conscious mind

433.text:
and plan for how to create 
a different outcome.

437.text:
If Amy had planned
for her date to go well,

441.text: things might have turned out differently.

445.text:
Our expectations about our ability
to get what we want

448.text:
have a very profound impact
on our emotional well-being.

452.text:
A large part of our brain is dedicated
to anticipating rewards:

457.text:
rewards, to put it simply,
are all the things you want

467.text:
"A single dream is more powerful
than a thousand realities."

472.text: When you expect to get a reward,

475.text:
you feel positive emotions
like happiness and joy.

479.text:
When you don’t think
you're going to get what you want,

482.text:
you feel sadness, disappointment,
maybe even depression.

489.text:
The larger the gap between
what you expect and what you want,

496.text:
What do you do when what you want
doesn't match up with what you expect?

500.text:
There is only two ways
you can feel good in this situation.

503.text: You can give up wanting what you want,

506.text:
tell yourself it wasn’t
really worth the effort,

508.text: you didn't really want it anyway.

511.text:
Or you can change your expectations
to match up with what you want,

516.text: so that you can take consistent action.

522.text: I'm going to give you three simple steps

524.text:
that will help you begin to shift
your expectations.

527.text:
What I want you to do right now though
is imagine an upcoming future event:

532.text:
it can be a goal
that you're trying to achieve,

538.text:
an upcoming holiday event
with your family.

544.text:
What I want you to do
for step number one is:

549.text:
"How is what I'm expecting
making me feel?"

554.text:
If you're expecting something 
positive to happen

556.text:
then you're going to be feeling
really good about it,

559.text: and you can stop right there.

561.text: No need to fix positive emotions.

564.text:
If you're expecting something
you don’t want,

567.text:
then you are going to be feeling
a negative emotion

577.text:
Those are all signs that you have
some negative expectations

589.text:
"What would I like to have
happen instead?"

592.text:
What this question identifies is what
you really do want in this situation.

596.text:
What you want, is oftentimes
the very thing that you are not expecting.

601.text:
Remember, you want to win the lottery,
but you don't expect to.

609.text:
"What do I need to do
to make what I want happen?"

614.text:
When you have a negative expectation
about a future event,

617.text:
it's because you’re focused
on all the things that could go wrong,

622.text: why it's not going to work out for you.

626.text:
You're not generating thoughts and ideas
about how to make it go right.

632.text:
When you see a plan
laid out in front of you

634.text: for how to get what you want,

636.text:
your assessment of the situation
starts to change;

641.text: you begin to see the possibility.

644.text: This is where the shift happens.

648.text:
Every successful action
that you take towards that plan

655.text: I realize some of you might be thinking:

659.text: "I don’t expect this to work for me."

667.text: To be perfectly honest, several years ago,

669.text:
I may not have expected a simple process
like this to make a difference

674.text:
But I was working
with a very depressed patient

677.text:
I had been treating him
for about six months.

681.text: We had done so much work together,

683.text:
but nothing we did seemed
to make any difference.

688.text:
"Where is the light
at the end of the tunnel?"

692.text:
He looked at me with one
of the blankest stares

697.text:
After that day, I started asking 
all my patients this question,

700.text: and I was startled to realize

702.text:
that many of them looked at me
in the exact same way.

706.text:
They didn’t dare to dream about how
their lives could be different,

709.text:
because they didn’t believe
it was possible.

712.text:
So I started to change
the focus of my work

714.text:
to almost exclusively helping
my patients shift those expectations,

718.text:
so that they could find their light
at the end of the tunnel.

723.text:
changing your expectations 
can significantly improve your life.

728.text:
I've witnessed some very
awe-inspiring transformations.

733.text:
Within a year, had quit his dead-end job
and started his own successful company.

739.text: When you're motivated by what you want,

744.text: In the words of Henry Ford,

746.text:
"Whether you think you can
or think you can’t, you are right."

752.text:
Your past isn’t what defines
who you are or where you are going.

758.text:
It’s your expectations of the future
that limit you most.

769.text:
You can choose to take action
based on what you want.

775.text:
you give yourself the opportunity
to step out of the past,

780.text:
and create the life
that you truly want to live.
